item.text: Lesson 77
3rd conditional

Explanation.text: Before we think about the 3rd conditional, we should remind ourselves of the 1st conditional and 2nd conditional:

item.text: 1st conditional
"if" + present + "will do" = real possibility
If I go to the park tomorrow, I will play football
2nd conditional
"if" + past + "would do" = only imagining
If I went to the park tomorrow, I would play football
When do we use the first conditional?
We use the first conditional to communicate that we think something is a real possibility in the future.
What is its construction?
Its construction is "if" plus present plus "will do".
Give me an example, please.
If he sees his friend this evening, he will say "hello".
When do we use the second conditional?
We use the second conditional to communicate that we are only imagining something.
What is its construction?
Its construction is "if" plus past plus "would do".
Give me an example, please.
If she went to the North Pole next week, she would feel very cold.
3rd conditional
"if" + past perfect + "would have done" = imagining in the past
If I had gone to the park yesterday, I would have played football

Explanation.text: We use the 3rd conditional to communicate that we are imagining something in the past that did not really happen. Its construction is “If“ + past perfect + “would have done“. The sentence “If I had gone to the park yesterday, I would have played football“ means that, in fact, I did not go to the park yesterday, and I did not play football; I am only imagining.

item.text: When do we use the third conditional?
We use the third conditional when we are imagining something in the past that did not really happen.
What is its construction?
Its construction is "if" plus past perfect plus "would have done".
Give me an example, please.
If she had studied harder, she would have succeeded in the exam last month.

Explanation.text: Notice that, in the 3rd conditional, we put the word “have“ and the past participle after the word “would“. For example, we say “I would have taken“; “you would have taken“; “he would have taken“ etc.

item.text: In the third conditional what do we put after the word would?
In the third conditional we put the word "have" and the past participle after the word "would".
Give me some examples, please.
He would have slept. She would have written. They would have eaten.
If you had been born in England, which language would you have spoken as a child?
If I had been born in England, I would have spoken English as a child.
Were you, in fact, born in England?
No, I wasn't, in fact, born in England. I was born in Japan.
Did you find £100 on the street yesterday?
No, I didn't find a £100 on the street yesterday.
But if you had found £100 on the street yesterday, what would you have done with it?
If I had found £100 on the street yesterday, I would have taken it to the police station.
If you had not decided to study English, which language would you have studied instead?
If I had not decided to study English, I would have studied French instead.
If you had not come to school last week, what would you have done instead?
If I had not come to school last week, I would have gone on holiday stayed at home etc.
diary
What do people use diaries for?
People use diaries to help them remember things that they have done or things that they need to do.
character
What kind of character do you like to see in a person?
I like to see a friendly character in a person.
really
Have you ever got up really early?
Yes, I sometimes got up really early.
For what reason?
To go to work.
If you are driving a car on a long journey and suddenly felt really tired, what would you do?
If I were driving a car on a long journey and suddenly felt really tired, I'd stop the car, buy a cup of coffee and wait until I felt more awake.
ran
What's the past of "run"?
The past of "run" is "ran".
If you ran against him or me etc. who do you think could win?
If I ran against him, I think I would win.
improve
coach
How can we improve our English?
We can improve our English by practicing a lot, reading a lot etc.
Why do even the best tennis players need a coach?
Even the best tennis players need a coach to help them to improve their game.
Is it cheaper to travel by coach or by train in your country?
It's cheaper to travel by coach in my country.
Adverbs formed from adjectives

Explanation.text: As you have already seen, one very common way of forming adverbs is by adding the letters “ly“ to the adjective. For example, “careful – carefully“; “dangerous – dangerously“; “useless – uselessly“ etc.

item.text: Tell me one very common way of forming adverbs from adjectives.
One very common way of forming adverbs from adjectives is by adding the letters 'l' 'y' to the adjective.
Give me some examples, please.
bad - badly; quick - quickly etc.
flew
What's the path to "fly"?
The pastor "fly" is "flew".
If you flew around the world in a straight line, would you finish in the same place as you had started?
Yes, if I flew around the world in a straight line, I'd finish in the same place as I had started.
If a bird flew into this room, what did you do?
If a bird flew into this room, I'd probably tried to catch it
wool
Which animal do we get wool from?
We get wool from a sheep
What can we make from wool?
We can make pullovers, hats and scarves from wool.
Possessive case of plural nouns ending in "s"
apostrophe
case
How do we form the possessive case of singular nouns like "girl", "man", "child" etc.?
We form the possessive case of singular nouns like "girl", "man", "child" etc. by adding an apostrophe and the letter 's'.
Give me some examples, please.
The girl's coat. The old man's hat. A child's book.
How do we form the possessive case of plural nouns that do not end in 's' such as "men", "women", "children" etc.?
We form the possessive case of plural nouns that do not end in 's' such as "men", "women", "children" etc. in the same way by adding an apostrophe and the letter 's'.
Give me some examples, please.
The old men's hats. Children's books. Women's clothes.
How do we form the possessive case of a plural noun which already ends in 's'?
We formed the possessive case of a plural noun which already ends in 's' just by adding an apostrophe, but no 's'.
Give me some examples, please.
The girls' coats; the workers' clothes; ladies' dresses.
What do footballers shirts have written on their backs?
Footballers shirts have numbers written on their backs.
kick
What am I doing?
You're kicking the table.
coast
certain
Can the English coast be seen from the coast of France?
Yes, on certain days, the English coast can be seen from the coast of France.
tire
Do you ever tire of speaking?
Yes, I sometimes tire of speaking.

Dictation.text:
Dictation 48
What have they just done?
They’ve just learnt that we use the 1st conditional to communicate that we think something is a real possibility.
Its construction is “if” + present + “will do”.
In the 2nd conditional, we use the past tense to communicate that we are only imagining something.
We use “would” followed by the infinitive without “to” to talk about the imagined result.
